زمان گذشته کامل - past perfect tense
The Past Perfect tense in English is composed of two parts: had + the past participle of the main verb.

The past perfect refers to a time earlier than before now. It is used to make it clear that one event happened before another in the past. It does not matter which event is mentioned first - the tense makes it clear which one happened first.


PAST PERFECT + JUST
'Just' is used with the past perfect to refer to an event that was only a short time earlier than before now.

~ I had saved my document before the computer crashed.
~ He was very tired because he hadn't slept well.
~ The train had just left when I arrived at the station.

tip: 'd is used for both "would" and "had".
that means this phrase "we 'd" could be either we had or we would. How do figure it out? 
easily; with the verb:
We had arrived. (past participle)
We would arrive.

Best definition about present simple and present continutes times. Where we should use them in action?

I learned it from my coursera class.

Present Simple:
Use it when: Happening all the time or usual activity
e.g.: I am a programmer. I study everyday. I live in fucking Iran. I work at ATA company.

Present Continuous:
Use it when:  Actions that are happening now 
e.g.: I'm reading this text and learning it.
future tense, will vs be going to usage in fluent speaking

Both are correct and have same meaning (future). So don't worry that much about them.

For pre-planned ones, use be going to: I 'm going to migrate to Germany in the next year.

For instand and quick decisions, use will: That bag looks heavy. I'll help you.

For predictions, both can be used. For example, I think the food in Argentina will be spicy.
continues tense vs perfect tense vs perfect continues tense
Present Perfect vs Present Perfect Continutues (resturant closing example)

Both start from a point in the past and happening until now. 

Present Perfect => The action or job is done and finished

Present Perfect Continutes => The action is on-going and not finished (will continute further)


Tip1:
Work, Live => No difference between two tenses

Tip2: Sometimes we cannot use perfect continues tense like statitive verb like be, love, belong, prefer etc (not important that much)
Here in first sentense, means all restaurants are closed but in second one, they are closing, but still there are restaurants which probably are open.

Best method of Shadowing after research and watching YouTube videos

- Shodowing is mainly without stopping the video and copying the sound and intonation of the speaker meaning being exactly like her/him
- But in that case it would be hard and not works as expected because we just want to say things fast but not accurate
- Better approach is seperate videos to smaller chunks and stop the video, copy and imitate the section and go ahead
- After finishing with this method, now go for long version method, but record your voice
- Hear your voice and compare with original one


TIPS:
* For videos, turn off the subtitle. Copy the speaker voice. Subtitles give us a reader's voice which is not good.
* Listen carefully before trying to speak. (and yes, it takes time but practice is very important). Even a teacher asks his strudents to hear 3 times before saying it!

Modal verbs? Rules of using a modal verb?

May / Might / Must / Can / Will / Should / Would / Could
(Shall and Ought to are never used in American English at-least)

There are 3 rules to using modal verbs:

○ Don't change the modal verbs
– He should clean his room

○ Simple verb comes directly after modal verb (infinitive verb, meaning without ing, to, s, etc)
– I can help you with that (not I can to hlep or I can helping you)

○ Questions
– Will we arrive to the movie?
– Can I go to dinner with you?
Conversation tips: Expressing worry about something phrases

○ I'm kind of worried about it
○ I'm a little anxious about it
○ I'm pretty nervous about it

○ I'm sure you'll be fine
○ I'm sure you'll do fine
○ Don't worry. Everything will work out

Consensus vs Unanimous:
Often people use the term unanimity and consensus synonymously.
a consensus-oriented process is one in which people work together to reach as much agreement as possible. Unanimity (or unanimous consent) is more specific. It refers to the outcome of a vote showing all members are agreed. Consensus is the process. Unanimity is one possible result of a consensus process.

~ a lack of consensus about the aims of the project
~ The general consensus was that technology was a good thing.

Review of my current strategies toward improving my English proficiany (English Learning) { after a lot of R&D }

* Private English Tutor

* Listen a lot { to podcasts and recorded conversations, content matters so don't only limit yourself to textboxs. Read about the world and interesting things happen around you like WION news!, it's completely valid! }

* Record your conversation { doing it with self-talking }

* Surround yourself with English { doing everything in English like XRP searches, Workouts exercise, talking to yourself when developing, All apps and To-Dos, etc }

* Practice with Music and Movies { Music at mornings, Movies I'm not sure yet }

* Read aloud {
    - Has two reasons 1-Bulid face muscles 2-The real, correct English because writer took time for best English }

    > Do it when watching daily news for the second time or watching the dev videos. Sometimes manipulate the sentences which helps a lot but needs active studying and can't be when you are cooking for example
    > I do it when reading somethings and when I'm coding in VS and talking to myself and reading English web pages
}

** Talk to yourself {
    - Think it as think out load meaing it is your toughts but you are saying them load, that's all!
    - Speak topic-base which for you is mainly the dev subjects
    - Record it to check later

    > Imagine: Give speech as a conference presenter about dev subjects { Record it }
    > Discuss about every clips or movies you see with yourself. Where it wants to be daily news, workout train or a dev clip. Stop it or after its end, talk about it with yourself freely without fearing any mistakes
        --> Tell yourself after watching them, OK, what's my opinion? How do I feel? What was the point of this video or audio?
        --> e.g. I can think about OK, how I tell the story from prespective of other character? How if I go to head of this other person? And what their prespective be.
            > I think that ....
            > If you couldn't express yourself or a feeling or anything, write it down and go for it, search and the next time you will be more prepared

}

** Improve pronunciation { I use Elsa Speak }

** Shadowing speech {
    - divide to chunks, listen carefully
    - imitate the chunk
    - manipulate the sentences { not part of the shadowing technique, but very effective and doable here because it's an active studying }
    - imitate the whole speech

    > Implement it on English Business Pod podcasts { each day one podcast and one shadowing }

   > Learn with voicing to others. Just don't keep stoping and strating over midway! It's not a test! { Check afterward for fluency, pronounciation and grammer mistakes. Notice your mistakes as well as take notes or create Anki cards if necessary and try to not repeat the mistakes again and improve. }
}
